 MessageÂ fromÂ theÂ SeniorÂ DirectorÂ ForÂ developingÂ countriesÂ toÂ participateÂ fullyÂ inÂ theÂ globalÂ economy,Â theyÂ mustÂ participateÂ fullyÂ inÂ internationalÂ trade.Â EconomistsÂ likeÂ toÂ talkÂ aboutÂ naturalÂ lawsÂ ofÂ marketsÂ andÂ exchange,Â butÂ tradeÂ atÂ theÂ highÂ levelÂ ofÂ globalizedÂ marketsÂ doesÂ notÂ happenÂ ofÂ itsÂ ownÂ accord.Â CountriesÂ needÂ toÂ haveÂ inÂ placeÂ theÂ physical,Â procedural,Â regulatory,Â andÂ legalÂ structuresÂ thatÂ makeÂ produce,Â goods,Â andÂ servicesÂ flowÂ smoothlyÂ fromÂ fieldÂ andÂ factoryÂ acrossÂ bordersÂ toÂ customers.Â Â

MaritimeÂ gatewaysÂ connectÂ countriesâ€”includingÂ landlockedÂ countriesâ€”andÂ regionsÂ toÂ theÂ restÂ ofÂ theÂ world.Â TheyÂ areÂ centersÂ ofÂ theÂ physicalÂ transferÂ ofÂ goodsÂ betweenÂ shippingÂ andÂ landÂ transport,Â andÂ viceÂ versa.Â TheyÂ areÂ alsoÂ centersÂ ofÂ informationÂ andÂ financialÂ exchangeÂ andÂ forÂ definingÂ theÂ statusÂ ofÂ goods.Â AÂ wideÂ rangeÂ ofÂ operatorsÂ engageÂ inÂ theseÂ processes.Â ThisÂ complexÂ arrayÂ ofÂ activityÂ takesÂ time,Â andÂ theÂ amountÂ ofÂ timeÂ aÂ shipmentÂ waitsÂ atÂ theÂ portÂ (technically,Â itsÂ dwellâ€timeÂ atÂ theÂ gateway)Â representsÂ aÂ significantÂ portionÂ ofÂ theÂ totalÂ deliveryÂ timeÂ fromÂ theÂ arrivalÂ ofÂ aÂ shipÂ inÂ portÂ toÂ theÂ deliveryÂ ofÂ goodsÂ toÂ theirÂ finalÂ destination.Â MovingÂ goodsÂ throughÂ aÂ gatewayÂ requiresÂ significantÂ paperwork.Â DocumentationÂ includesÂ theÂ transferÂ ofÂ informationÂ andÂ moneyÂ betweenÂ allÂ theÂ differentÂ actors.Â ItÂ isÂ anÂ iterativeÂ processÂ inÂ whichÂ mostÂ ofÂ theÂ informationÂ onÂ theÂ goodsÂ tradedÂ isÂ sharedÂ amongÂ agenciesÂ (clearanceÂ byÂ customs,Â releaseÂ byÂ shippingÂ agent,Â releaseÂ byÂ terminalÂ operator,Â etc.).Â InÂ thisÂ process,Â customsÂ administrationÂ playÂ aÂ pivotalÂ roleÂ andÂ hasÂ generallyÂ beenÂ perceivedÂ asÂ theÂ mostÂ importantÂ obstacleÂ orÂ sourceÂ ofÂ delayÂ (seeÂ BoxÂ 4.1Â inÂ theÂ nextÂ chapterÂ onÂ timeÂ releaseÂ studies).Â Accordingly,Â mostÂ effortsÂ toÂ reduceÂ portÂ dwellâ€timeÂ haveÂ beenÂ orientedÂ towardÂ improvingÂ customsÂ efficiency,Â notablyÂ throughÂ theÂ introductionÂ ofÂ informationÂ technologyÂ (IT)Â systemsÂ toÂ assistÂ inÂ theÂ clearanceÂ process.Â Â
TheÂ inlandÂ transportÂ segmentÂ ofÂ theÂ corridorÂ enablesÂ theÂ physicalÂ movementÂ ofÂ goodsÂ betweenÂ theÂ maritimeÂ gatewayÂ andÂ theÂ inlandÂ terminal.Â AlongÂ theÂ wayÂ areÂ moreÂ potentialÂ bottlenecks;Â ifÂ aÂ shipmentÂ doesÂ notÂ haveÂ documentsÂ indicatingÂ itÂ hasÂ passedÂ throughÂ customs,Â itÂ willÂ beÂ heldÂ upÂ atÂ theÂ borderÂ crossing.Â CompetitionÂ betweenÂ inlandÂ transportationÂ firms,Â particularlyÂ inÂ theÂ truckingÂ industry,Â canÂ reduceÂ delaysÂ withoutÂ compromisingÂ customsÂ revenuesÂ andÂ canÂ beÂ achievedÂ throughÂ reformÂ ofÂ roadÂ transportÂ policy.Â EffectiveÂ reforms,Â includingÂ theÂ establishmentÂ ofÂ inlandÂ terminals,Â leadÂ toÂ moreÂ efficientÂ andÂ saferÂ multimodalÂ transportÂ systems.Â
ThereÂ areÂ twoÂ reasonsÂ toÂ establishÂ inlandÂ terminals:Â (i)Â toÂ serveÂ aÂ denselyÂ populatedÂ areaÂ receivingÂ imports,Â suchÂ asÂ capitalÂ citiesÂ andÂ economicÂ centers,Â andÂ (ii)Â toÂ expandÂ localÂ economicÂ activities,Â forÂ example,Â inÂ areasÂ dependentÂ onÂ miningÂ orÂ agriculturalÂ exports.Â TheÂ challengesÂ forÂ internationalÂ tradeÂ logisticsÂ differÂ accordingÂ toÂ theÂ characteristicsÂ ofÂ eachÂ ofÂ theseÂ scenarios.Â ForÂ theÂ mainÂ consumptionÂ centers,Â inlandÂ terminalsÂ provideÂ facilitiesÂ requiredÂ forÂ clearanceÂ ofÂ highÂ volumesÂ ofÂ goodsÂ priorÂ toÂ finalÂ distribution.Â GoodsÂ areÂ transportedÂ alongÂ theÂ corridorÂ toÂ theirÂ destinationÂ underÂ aÂ customsÂ transitÂ regime.Â DeliveryÂ requiresÂ anÂ importÂ declarationÂ forÂ finalÂ customsÂ clearance.Â ForÂ largeÂ shippersÂ withÂ availableÂ storageÂ spaceÂ andÂ adequateÂ handlingÂ equipment,Â theÂ customsÂ clearanceÂ processÂ canÂ takeÂ placeÂ rapidlyÂ onÂ theirÂ property.Â However,Â theÂ majorityÂ ofÂ shippersÂ mustÂ clearÂ theirÂ goodsÂ atÂ aÂ customsÂ bondedÂ areaÂ atÂ theÂ destinationÂ bureau.Â TheseÂ inlandÂ terminalsÂ mustÂ accommodateÂ twoÂ typesÂ ofÂ processes.Â OneÂ allowsÂ customsÂ clearanceÂ andÂ onwardÂ deliveryÂ onÂ theÂ sameÂ truck,Â whereÂ onlyÂ theÂ efficiencyÂ ofÂ theÂ clearanceÂ processÂ matters.Â ButÂ terminalsÂ mustÂ alsoÂ accommodateÂ offloadingÂ andÂ warehousingÂ ofÂ theÂ goodsÂ forÂ customsÂ clearanceÂ andÂ onwardÂ deliveryÂ onÂ aÂ differentÂ truck.Â InÂ theseÂ cases,Â adequateÂ handlingÂ equipmentÂ andÂ storageÂ facilitiesÂ areÂ critical.Â InlandÂ terminalsÂ mustÂ thereforeÂ combineÂ physicalÂ facilitiesÂ withÂ borderÂ agencyÂ operations.Â

5.Â TFFÂ SignificantÂ MilestonesÂ andÂ LessonsÂ LearnedÂ PerhapsÂ theÂ singleÂ mostÂ importantÂ contributionÂ ofÂ theÂ experienceÂ gainedÂ overÂ theÂ pastÂ fiveÂ yearsÂ ofÂ TradeÂ FacilitationÂ FacilityÂ operationsÂ hasÂ beenÂ theÂ elevationÂ ofÂ tradeÂ facilitationÂ asÂ aÂ priorityÂ inÂ theÂ globalÂ communityÂ andÂ aÂ majorÂ endeavorÂ forÂ developingÂ countries.Â StrengtheningÂ tradeÂ linkagesÂ withinÂ regions,Â providingÂ landlockedÂ countriesÂ withÂ accessÂ toÂ seaports,Â reductionÂ ofÂ transitÂ costs,Â streamliningÂ ofÂ regulations,Â improvingÂ tradeÂ transparencyÂ andÂ productÂ qualityâ€” theseÂ areÂ amongÂ theÂ criticalÂ issuesÂ addressedÂ byÂ TFFÂ toÂ helpÂ bringÂ lowerâ€incomeÂ countriesÂ intoÂ theÂ worldÂ ofÂ internationalÂ trade.Â IncreasedÂ developingÂ countryÂ participationÂ inÂ internationalÂ tradeÂ isÂ increasinglyÂ understoodÂ asÂ aÂ vitalÂ elementÂ inÂ theÂ WorldÂ BankÂ GroupÂ endeavorÂ toÂ eliminateÂ extremeÂ povertyÂ andÂ boostÂ sharedÂ prosperity,Â theÂ Bankâ€™sÂ TwinÂ Goals.Â

doc.repnme: Unlocking trade for low-income countries : report of the trade facilitation facility, 2009-2015
doc.abstracts: The trade facilitation facility (TFF) was launched to help low-income countries improve their competitiveness by reducing the costs of engaging in international trade, thus supporting their efforts to reduce poverty and achieve the millennium development goals. This report summarizes the outcomes of the TFF between its establishment in 2009 and its end in 2015. The report highlights and reviews the accomplishments and lessons learned of TFF; it also discusses and reflects the perspective of task team leaders and relevant World Bank Group officials on the Bank Group’s continuing work in the trade facilitation sphere. The report presents results of TFF-funded activities and programs managed by staff from a large cross section of Bank Group sectors, including transport, agriculture, governance (customs), international trade, and private sector development. The report is organized as follows: chapter one give introduction. Chapter two provides an overview of the TFF portfolio. Chapter three looks at TFF as enabler of deepening regional integration, highlighting some of the facility’s accomplishments from a geographic and thematic perspective, particularly the extent to which TFF complemented Bank infrastructure operations and nurtured progress on trade facilitation instruments that countries and regional economic communities (RECs) have adopted but failed to implement. Chapter four, expanding thematic insights, addresses conceptual themes in trade facilitation. Chapter five, conclusions and contributions, sums up the areas in which TFF has contributed to moving the regional and multilateral trade facilitation agenda.
